Key Match Events: David Warner and Mitchell Marsh threatened when the field was up, the former clever in creating angles behind square, the latter hitting powerfully through the ball. They seized 50 from the first five overs, but were respectively quelled for 25 and 45.
Rashid Khan's late assault all but stole the pursuit of 168 for eight in the final over, falling four runs short on 164 for seven.
Naveen-ul-Haq Murid stood out, a young quick with a fine action who faced down the charging Australians and emerged with three for 21.
Glenn Maxwell bettered the 10 runs per over that Australia really needed, taking on spinners and seamers alike, batting through to the close for 54 from 32 balls.
Rashid belted one more six and two fours, one of them just short of the rope, and couldn’t quite get there, with 16 from the over a commendable effort as he finished on 48 not out.
Pre-Game Insights: Australia went into their final group match of the Twenty20 World Cup with an ambitious yet straightforward task: execute the perfect mugging of Afghanistan in Adelaide to boost their own net run rate for the tournament ahead of England’s.
Post-Match Reflections: Australia’s fate is now in other hands, with their only path to the semi-finals requiring a Sri Lanka win over England on Saturday.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Today’s Afghanistan is an altogether hardier side than the one that shipped 417 runs against Australia in the 50-over World Cup of 2015.
The match was never fully Australia’s way.
Aaron Finch, the captain, and the finisher Tim David ruled out with hamstring injuries, replaced after a tournament on the sidelines by Cameron Green and Steve Smith.
Others: The replacements faced six balls and made seven runs between them, while among the fast bowlers Kane Richardson replaced Mitchell Starc and was lashed for 48 runs in his allotment.
